title.children: Australia is in another COVID wave, but it's not like the others

image.altText: More revelations in the Jeffrey Epstein investigation

title.children: Jeffrey Epstein victims reach $430 million settlement with JPMorgan Chase bank

title.children: Does this box contain the answer to the problem of space junk?

image.altText: A Parramatta NRL player with a cut in the corner of his left eye flicks a pass to his left during a game.

items.synopsis: NSW make four changes for Origin II on June 21, with Parramatta playmaker Mitchell Moses and Souths hooker Damien Cook coming in along with two debutants.

title.children: NSW bring in four players to side for Origin II

image.altText: A Golden Globe award, shaped like a globe on a pedestal with a strip of movie film wrapped around it.

items.synopsis: The Hollywood Foreign Press Association (HFPA) sells the Golden Globes to private investors, spelling the end of the embattled non-profit after 80 years of handing out the entertainment awards.

title.children: Golden Globes to become a 'commercial enterprise' as the Hollywood Foreign Press group disbands

image.altText: An ASX board shot by John Gunn in Deccember 2022.

items.synopsis: Commonwealth Bank data shows consumers spent more on health and fitness last month, but it expects further interest rate rises to dampen demand. The ASX is weaker despite 13-month high on Wall Street.

title.children: CBA says spending higher in May but rate hikes set to bite, ASX falls on commodity prices

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Despite the slowing economy, the National Australia Bank has raised its forecasts for official interest rates for the second time in a week. It now thinks the Reserve Bank will lift the official cash rate to 4.6 per cent to curb inflation, seeing possible rate increases of 0.25 per cent in both July and August. That's to curb high inflation and the risk of rising prices leading to more calls for higher wages. The NAB's economics team, led by chief economist, Alan Oster, expects the economy to slow to its slowest pace since the 1990s recession. "Taking rates to 4.6 per cent will weigh more heavily on growth and we have revised down our expectations for  growth over 2023 to just 0.5 per cent and pulled back expectations for 2024 to around 0.9 per cent." "That sees  unemployment rise more quickly and reach 5 per cent by end 2024." "We still see the RBA cutting interest rates back towards neutral in 2024 as a “forward-looking” central bank  sees the slowing in growth and unemployment rising.... and it becomes clearer inflation is returning to target."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NAB tips RBA to lift rates to 4.6 per cent

children.content: Despite the slowing economy, the National Australia Bank has raised its forecasts for official interest rates for the second time in a week.
It now thinks the Reserve Bank will lift the official cash rate to 4.6 per cent to curb inflation, seeing possible rate increases of 0.25 per cent in both July and August.
That's to curb high inflation and the risk of rising prices leading to more calls for higher wages.
The NAB's economics team, led by chief economist, Alan Oster, expects the economy to slow to its slowest pace since the 1990s recession.

"Taking rates to 4.6 per cent will weigh more heavily on growth and we have revised down our expectations for  growth over 2023 to just 0.5 per cent and pulled back expectations for 2024 to around 0.9 per cent."
"That sees  unemployment rise more quickly and reach 5 per cent by end 2024."

"We still see the RBA cutting interest rates back towards neutral in 2024 as a “forward-looking” central bank  sees the slowing in growth and unemployment rising.... and it becomes clearer inflation is returning to target."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has come off its lows over lunchtime. The ASX 200 index is down slightly, after weaker commodity prices pulled the benchmark index lower in the morning. Miners and energy stocks are still weighing on the market, while technology is leading the gains after big tech drove Wall Street overnight. Domino's Pizza (-7.9 per cent) is the worst performer in the ASX 200, while uranium firm Paladin Energy (+11.5 per cent) is the best performer. Cyber security firm Tesserent has jumped 145 per cent after it accepted a $176 million takeover bid from defence, security and transport giant Thales.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Shares lower at lunchtime

children.content: The Australian share market has come off its lows over lunchtime.
The ASX 200 index is down slightly, after weaker commodity prices pulled the benchmark index lower in the morning.
Miners and energy stocks are still weighing on the market, while technology is leading the gains after big tech drove Wall Street overnight.
Domino's Pizza (-7.9 per cent) is the worst performer in the ASX 200, while uranium firm Paladin Energy (+11.5 per cent) is the best performer.
Cyber security firm Tesserent has jumped 145 per cent after it accepted a $176 million takeover bid from defence, security and transport giant Thales.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Home prices rose over the first few months of the year according to the Bureau of Statistics despite higher interest rates. The total value of Australia's homes increased by $140 billion to $9.9 trillion over the March quarter. That's a lot of money, although the value of residential dwellings did reach $10.2 trillion for the first time in March last year. The mean price of Australian homes lifted by $8,500 to $896,000 with the total number of dwellings up 52,000 to just over 11 million over the first three months of 2023. New South Wales has the highest home prices in the country with a mean price of $1.15 million. The value of Australian homes rose in all states except Tasmania, the Northern Territory, and the ACT. The data from the ABS is a bit delayed, with the latest data from property analysts CoreLogic showing that home values increased for the third month in a row in May. Here's more from Stephanie Chalmers.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian homes worth $9.9 trillion

featuredLink.title: Rosemary paid $35k for a modest Sydney home. When it went to auction 45 years later, she thought she 'was going to faint'

children.content: Home prices rose over the first few months of the year according to the Bureau of Statistics despite higher interest rates.
The total value of Australia's homes increased by $140 billion to $9.9 trillion over the March quarter.

props.alt: Graph showing value of Australian homes

children.content: Home values
(ABS)
That's a lot of money, although the value of residential dwellings did reach $10.2 trillion for the first time in March last year.
The mean price of Australian homes lifted by $8,500 to $896,000 with the total number of dwellings up 52,000 to just over 11 million over the first three months of 2023.
New South Wales has the highest home prices in the country with a mean price of $1.15 million.
The value of Australian homes rose in all states except Tasmania, the Northern Territory, and the ACT.
The data from the ABS is a bit delayed, with the latest data from property analysts CoreLogic showing that home values increased for the third month in a row in May.
Here's more from Stephanie Chalmers.
